slides.title: PolicyCenter Introduction: Accounts
slides.notes: Title slide for PolicyCenter Introduction, Lesson 1: Accounts. This lesson covers the fundamentals of account management in Guidewire PolicyCenter, including account creation, name clearance, producer codes, and the Account Summary Dashboard.
slides.narration: Welcome to PolicyCenter Introduction. This is Lesson 1, and we're starting with one of the most fundamental concepts you'll work with as a Guidewire developer: Accounts. Accounts are the cornerstone of the PolicyCenter data model. Everything starts here, from quoting to binding policies, managing renewals, and tracking customer relationships. By the end of this lesson, you'll understand how accounts relate to policies, how name clearance works, and how to navigate the Account Summary Dashboard. Let's get started.
slides.ocrText: Accounts

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.notes: Learning objectives for this lesson: Understand the purpose of accounts in PolicyCenter, distinguish between person and company accounts, explain the account-to-policy relationship, describe the name clearance process, identify producer codes and organizations, and navigate the Account Summary Dashboard.
slides.narration: Here are our learning objectives for this lesson. By the end, you should be able to explain the purpose of accounts in PolicyCenter and why they exist separately from policies. You'll understand the difference between person and company accounts, how accounts relate to policies through the insured relationship, and how the name clearance process prevents duplicate accounts. We'll also cover producer codes and organizations, and you'll get hands-on with the Account Summary Dashboard. These are foundational concepts that will come up repeatedly throughout your Guidewire career.

slides.title: What is an Account?
slides.notes: An account in PolicyCenter represents a customer relationship. It is the top-level entity that groups together all policies, contacts, activities, and documents associated with a particular customer. Think of it as the container for everything related to a single customer or business.
slides.narration: So what exactly is an account in PolicyCenter? Think of an account as the container for an entire customer relationship. It's the top-level entity in the data model that groups together everything about a customer: their policies, contacts, activities, documents, and billing information. This separation between the account and individual policies is a deliberate design decision. It gives insurers the flexibility to manage the customer relationship holistically, rather than on a policy-by-policy basis. As a developer, understanding this distinction is critical because it impacts how you query data, build UI components, and implement business logic.

slides.title: Accounts vs. Policies
slides.originalNotes: Accounts provide the ability to keep customer information separate from policies. An account gives PolicyCenter users the flexibility to create and manage a customer's account independent of any policies that may be associated with the account. The ability to manage an account separately from a policy is useful when providing both policies and accounts visibility to different types of users.
slides.notes: Accounts provide the ability to keep customer information separate from policies. An account gives PolicyCenter users the flexibility to create and manage a customer's account independent of any policies that may be associated with the account. The ability to manage an account separately from a policy is useful when providing both policies and accounts visibility to different types of users.
slides.narration: This is a key architectural concept. Accounts and policies are separate entities in the data model, and that's intentional. An account represents the customer, while a policy represents a specific insurance contract. By keeping them separate, PolicyCenter gives users the flexibility to manage customer information independently of any specific policy. Think about why this matters in practice: a customer service rep might need to update a customer's address, and that change should propagate to all their policies. Or an underwriter might need to see all policies under one commercial account to assess overall risk. This separation also enables different permission models. You can give certain users access to account-level data without exposing specific policy details, or vice versa.

slides.title: Account Holder Types
slides.originalNotes: A person or a company may be an account holder.
slides.notes: A person or a company may be an account holder. Person accounts represent individual customers, while company accounts represent business entities. The account holder type determines which fields are available and how the account is displayed throughout the application.
slides.narration: An account holder can be either a person or a company. This is a fundamental distinction in the data model. A person account represents an individual customer, such as someone buying a personal auto or homeowner's policy. A company account represents a business entity, like a construction firm or a retail chain. The account holder type matters because it determines the fields available on the account. A person account has fields like first name, last name, and date of birth. A company account has fields like company name, FEIN, and industry code. From a developer perspective, you'll encounter this distinction in the entity model, the UI configuration, and validation rules. The underlying entity uses subtypes to handle this polymorphism.

slides.title: Multiple Accounts per Contact
slides.originalNotes: Different accounts have different purposes. A single contact may hold multiple accounts.
slides.notes: Different accounts have different purposes. A single contact may hold multiple accounts. For example, an individual might have a personal auto account and a separate commercial account for their small business. Each account serves a distinct purpose and may be managed by different producers.
slides.narration: Here's something that often surprises new developers: a single contact can hold multiple accounts. Different accounts serve different purposes. For example, imagine John Smith. He might have a personal auto account managed by his local State Farm agent, and a separate commercial account for his landscaping business managed by a commercial lines broker. Each account can have its own producer, its own set of policies, and its own billing arrangements. This many-to-one relationship between accounts and contacts is important to understand when you're building search functionality or reporting. You need to be aware that finding a contact doesn't mean you've found all their accounts, and vice versa.

slides.title: Account-to-Policy Relationship
slides.originalNotes: An account can have zero, one or many associated policies. An account with at least one policy is referred to as •the insured". An account may have many separate, distinct "insureds“ aggregated within it as a related account. For example, General Motors could be an account with separate insureds (Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Pontiac) and separate policies for each insured. However, a policy can belong to only one account.
slides.notes: An account can have zero, one or many associated policies. An account with at least one policy is referred to as "the insured". An account may have many separate, distinct "insureds" aggregated within it as a related account. For example, General Motors could be an account with separate insureds (Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Pontiac) and separate policies for each insured. However, a policy can belong to only one account.
slides.narration: Let's look at how accounts and policies relate to each other. An account can have zero, one, or many associated policies. An account with no policies is perfectly valid. Maybe a quote was started but never bound, or the customer is in the process of being set up. Once an account has at least one active policy, the account holder is referred to as the insured. Now here's where it gets interesting for commercial lines. An account can contain multiple distinct insureds as related accounts. Take General Motors as an example. GM could be the parent account, with separate insureds for Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Pontiac, each with their own policies. However, and this is important, a policy can belong to only one account. It's a many-to-one relationship: many policies to one account, never the reverse.

slides.title: Name Clearance
slides.originalNotes:
When you try to create a new account in PolicyCenter, the application will search for a pre- existing account first by checking the name against one or more producer or account databases. PolicyCenter goes through name clearance to ensure that a person or company is not already an existing account, and that another producer does not represent them for the given policy type.

Name clearance is a relevant issue when the same account requests quotes or policies at different times while providing slightly different names(such as a company known as "Demo Deliveries", "Demo Deliveries Inc.", and "Demo Delivers"). PolicyCenter executes name clearance to determine if the named account exists. Based on the customer's business need, the end user can choose an existing account (if found) or create a new account.
slides.notes:
When you try to create a new account in PolicyCenter, the application will search for a pre-existing account first by checking the name against one or more producer or account databases. PolicyCenter goes through name clearance to ensure that a person or company is not already an existing account, and that another producer does not represent them for the given policy type.

Name clearance is a relevant issue when the same account requests quotes or policies at different times while providing slightly different names (such as a company known as "Demo Deliveries", "Demo Deliveries Inc.", and "Demo Delivers"). PolicyCenter executes name clearance to determine if the named account exists. Based on the customer's business need, the end user can choose an existing account (if found) or create a new account.
slides.narration: Name clearance is one of the most important processes in account management, and it's something you'll likely need to customize as a developer. When a user tries to create a new account, PolicyCenter doesn't just create it immediately. It first searches for pre-existing accounts by checking the name against producer and account databases. This prevents duplicates. Think about why this matters. The same customer might request quotes at different times with slightly different names. A company known as Demo Deliveries might also be entered as Demo Deliveries Inc. or even Demo Delivers. Name clearance catches these variations and presents potential matches to the user. The user then decides whether to use an existing account or create a new one. From a configuration standpoint, you can customize the name clearance search criteria, the matching algorithm, and the UI that presents results. This is a common customization point for implementations.

slides.title: Organizations and Producer Codes
slides.originalNotes:
When creating an account in PolicyCenter, you will need to provide an organization and a producer code. A producer is a generic term for a third party bringing business to the insurer. An organization is the group that a producer belongs to, and a producer code is a unique identifier assigned to the producer responsible for a policy or account. By including this information during account creation, the insurer can track the agent and agency that originally opened the account.

Sometimes, producers can pre- qualify an applicant. In PolicyCenter, producers are specified in the account information using a producer code, which is entered when creating the account. You can learn more about organizations and producers in the PolicyCenter Community Model Refer to the lesson, "Users, Groups, and Organizations".

slides.narration: When creating an account, you must provide an organization and a producer code. Let me break these down. A producer is a generic term for any third party that brings business to the insurer, typically an insurance agent or broker. An organization is the group that producer belongs to, like an agency or brokerage firm. And a producer code is the unique identifier assigned to that specific producer. This information is captured at account creation so the insurer can always track which agent and agency originated the business. This drives commission calculations, book-of-business reporting, and producer management workflows. As a developer, you'll work with the producer model extensively. Producers can also pre-qualify applicants in certain configurations. We'll dive deeper into organizations and producer codes in a later lesson on Users, Groups, and Organizations, but for now, just understand that every account is linked to a producer.

slides.title: Account Summary Dashboard
slides.originalNotes:
The Account Summary Dashboard provides several information panels that are important to customer service representatives, agents, and underwriters in addition to other insurance personnel. The Account Summary provides details about the account holder, a general overview of the account, billing details, current activities, and a list of all policies for the account Policy transactions, claims, related accounts, producers and locations are also on the Account Summary page.

The Billing section graphic shows aggregated information for accounts that are stored in the billing system. Information related to the next invoice and the last payment is also displayed per account.

Policy transactions, claims, related accounts, producers and locations are also on the Account Summary page.

The Billing section graphic shows aggregated information for accounts that are stored in the billing system. Information related to the next invoice and the last payment is also displayed per account.
slides.narration: The Account Summary Dashboard is the central hub for account management. This is typically the first screen users see when they open an account, and it's designed to give a complete picture at a glance. The dashboard includes panels for account holder details, a general overview, billing information, current activities, and a list of all associated policies. You'll also find policy transactions, claims history, related accounts, producer information, and locations. Pay attention to the Billing section. It shows aggregated billing data pulled from BillingCenter through the integration layer. You'll see the next invoice date, the last payment received, and the overall billing status. This integration between PolicyCenter and BillingCenter is something you'll work with frequently in real implementations.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.notes: PolicyCenter provides multiple ways to search for accounts. Users can search by account number, account holder name, phone number, or address. The search functionality supports partial matches and wildcard searches. Search results display key account information to help users identify the correct account.
slides.narration: Let's talk about account search, which is another area you'll frequently customize. PolicyCenter provides multiple ways to find an account. You can search by account number, account holder name, phone number, or address. The search supports partial matches, so entering just a few characters of the name will return potential results. Search results display key information like the account name, number, status, and producer to help users quickly identify the right account. From a developer perspective, the search functionality is highly configurable. You can add custom search criteria, modify the result columns, and even implement custom search algorithms for specific business requirements.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.notes: Locations on an account represent physical addresses associated with the customer. Locations are used for rating, territory determination, and policy-level address requirements. Account-level locations can be reused across multiple policies, ensuring consistency and reducing data entry.
slides.narration: Locations are another important piece of the account puzzle. They represent the physical addresses associated with the customer, such as business premises, mailing addresses, or insured property locations. Locations serve several critical functions in PolicyCenter. They're used for rating calculations, territory determination, and meeting policy-level address requirements. A key design principle is that account-level locations can be reused across multiple policies under that account. So if a commercial customer has ten locations, you enter them once at the account level, and then reference them from each policy that needs them. This reduces data entry and ensures consistency. As a developer, you'll work with location entities when configuring coverages, building rating algorithms, and customizing the submission workflow.

slides.title: Key Takeaways
slides.notes: Summary of key concepts covered in this lesson: accounts are separate from policies for flexibility, person and company account types use subtypes, one account maps to many policies (but not reverse), name clearance prevents duplicates, producer codes track business origination, and the Account Summary Dashboard is the central workspace.
slides.narration: Let's recap the key takeaways from this lesson. First, accounts and policies are intentionally separate in the data model. This gives insurers flexibility to manage customer relationships independent of specific policies. Second, accounts come in two types, person and company, implemented through entity subtypes. Third, the account-to-policy relationship is one-to-many: one account can have many policies, but a policy belongs to only one account. Fourth, name clearance is the process that prevents duplicate accounts during creation. Fifth, producer codes link accounts to the agents and agencies that originated the business. And finally, the Account Summary Dashboard is the central workspace for managing all account information. These concepts form the foundation for everything else we'll learn in PolicyCenter.
